user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_seek_:
```c
static int lfs_dir_seek_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir, lfs_off_t off) {
    // simply walk from head dir
    int err = lfs_dir_rewind_(lfs, dir);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // first two for ./..
    dir->pos = lfs_min(2, off);
    off -= dir->pos;

    // skip superblock entry
    dir->id = (off > 0 && lfs_pair_cmp(dir->head, lfs->root) == 0);

    while (off > 0) {
        if (dir->id == dir->m.count) {
            if (!dir->m.split) {
                return LFS_ERR_INVAL;
            }

            err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir->m, dir->m.tail);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }

            dir->id = 0;
        }

        int diff = lfs_min(dir->m.count - dir->id, off);
        dir->id += diff;
        dir->pos += diff;
        off -= diff;
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function lfs_dir_seek_:
static int lfs_dir_rewind_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir) {
    // reload the head dir
    int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir->m, dir->head);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    dir->id = 0;
    dir->pos = 0;
    return 0;
}
...
static int lfs_dir_fetch(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_mdir_t *dir, const lfs_block_t pair[2]) {
    // note, mask=-1, tag=-1 can never match a tag since this
    // pattern has the invalid bit set
    return (int)lfs_dir_fetchmatch(lfs, dir, pair,
            (lfs_tag_t)-1, (lfs_tag_t)-1, NULL, NULL, NULL);
}
...
static inline int lfs_pair_cmp(
        const lfs_block_t paira[2],
        const lfs_block_t pairb[2]) {
    return !(paira[0] == pairb[0] || paira[1] == pairb[1] ||
             paira[0] == pairb[1] || paira[1] == pairb[0]);
}
...
typedef uint32_t lfs_off_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
dir->id = (off > 0 && lfs_pair_cmp(dir->head, lfs->root) == 0);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The expression dir->id = (off > 0 && lfs_pair_cmp(dir->head, lfs->root) == 0); does not introduce unreachable code. The left operand (off > 0) can be true or false at runtime, and when it is true the call to lfs_pair_cmp is executed; when false the second operand is simply short‑circuited (defined behavior), not unreachable code. lfs_pair_cmp returns 0 or 1 (because of the ! operator), so the comparison == 0 yields a valid boolean value that is assigned to dir->id. Therefore Rule 2.1 is not violated by this fragment.
